Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: From the Slab to the Surface: Origin, Storage, Ascent and Eruption of Volatile-Bearing Magmas
Award.AbstractNarration:
On any given day, approximately 15-30 volcanoes worldwide are either in eruption or show strong signs of unrest (e.g., anomalously high rates of seismic activity, ground deformation, or gas emissions). Volcanic activity, including high-altitude eruptions of ash or emission of large volumes of gas, poses a significant hazard to people and property in the United States and worldwide. This is particularly true in Alaska, with over 10,000 passengers a day flying over 35 historically active volcanoes on North America/Asia flight routes. Although significant progress has been made in recent decades in understanding the physical processes occurring in the upper portions of the Earth's crust that lead directly to volcanic activity and associated unrest, there is a fundamental lack of understanding of how these shallow crustal processes link to and are controlled by the large-scale crustal tectonics and deep mantle melting that are ultimately responsible for arc volcanism. Specifically, although it is well understood that the amount of water and other volatiles dissolved in a magma plays a key role in its generation, ascent, and eruption, it is unclear why some arc volcanoes erupt 'wetter' magmas than others. Identifying large scale controls on magma volatile contents is thus critical for accurate forecasting of the frequency, volume, and explosivity of volcanic eruptions.

Here, we propose an integrated geochemical-geophysical study of the Unimak-Cleveland corridor of the Aleutian volcanic arc, which encompasses six volcanoes that have erupted in the past 25 years with a wide range of magmatic water contents. This relatively small corridor also exhibits a range of deep and upper-crustal seismicity, apparent magma storage depths, and depths to the subducting tectonic plate. Our goal is to link two normally disconnected big-picture problems: 1) the deep origin of magmas and volatiles, and 2) the formation and eruption of crustal magma reservoirs, which we propose to do by establishing the depth(s) of crustal magma reservoirs and pre-eruptive volatile contents throughout the corridor. The integrated study components include analysis of volcano- seismic events and magmatic volatile analysis. Existing seismic data catalogs contain ~ 14,000 events, and some samples of volcanic eruption products are already in hand. The existence of two actively erupting volcanoes in the corridor further motivates collection of simultaneous seismic, gas (in collaboration with the USGS Alaska Volcano Observatory) and tephra samples during eruption, that reflect active evolution of the magmatic system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Volcanoes exist because the mantle of the Earth below them is melting, generally due to a plate tectonic driving force. At subducting plate boundaries, the oceanic crust sinks into the mantle carrying with it seawater that is released at depth and drives mantle melting. The resulting magma rises and exsolves water to gas bubbles when it reaches within a few km of Earth’s surface. These bubbles cause explosive volcanic eruptions. Thus plate convergence leads to a large water cycle – from the subducting oceanic slab to the volcanic eruption back to atmosphere-ocean system. This NSF/GeoPrisms project asked the question: does the volcano know about the slab? Does the volcanic plumbing system reflect the subduction system? Or is the volcano largely controlled by upper crust structure and stress state? We went to a ~450 km section of the Aleutian volcanic chain in Alaska to answer these questions because here the subducting slab varies more in its depth beneath the volcanoes than anywhere else on Earth. 

This project involved two summer field seasons between Shishaldin and Cleveland volcanoes on  boats and helicopters, collecting volcanic rocks, and carrying out collaborative seismic experiments with scientists from the Carnegie Institution of Washington and the Alaska Volcano Observatory. Back in New York, PhD student Daniel Rasmussen spent four years studying these samples, painstakingly picking from the volcanic material hundreds of tiny olivine crystals that contained microscopic inclusion of trapped magmatic liquid, now quenched to glass. Rasmussen used Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy to measure the H2O and CO2 content of these glass inclusions, and electron microprobe and laser ablation mass spectrometry to measure a host of other major and minor elements.  With these data, he discovered that the ratio of H2O to K2O varied along the volcanic chain, increasing to the west, in concert with the shallowing of the depth to the subducting slab. This variation is consistent with shallower depths in the slab releasing lower temperature fluids that contain higher H2O/K2O. This is the first time such a relationship has been discovered, and it provides a clear link between the subducting slab and water content of the magmas that feed volcanoes. Rasmussen also discovered that the water content of parental magmas controls how deep in the crust magmas stall prior to eruption, and that this is a global phenomenon. Wetter magmas drive deeper crystallization and viscous stalling in the crust. This project, which also supported five undergraduates in research and training experiences, thus showed that both the type of magma and the architecture of the plumbing system are set by the flux of water from the subducting plate. Rasmussen successfully completed his Columbia University PhD and is now a Buck Postdoctoral Fellow at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington DC.
